00008  * as published by the Free Software Foundation.
00009  *
00010  * This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but
00011  * WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
00012  * MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the GNU
00013  * General Public License version 2 for more details (a copy is included
00014  * in the LICENSE file that accompanied this code).
00015  *
00016  * You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
00017  * version 2 along with this program; If not, see
00018  * http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-2.0.html
00019  *
00020  * GPL HEADER END
00021  */
00022 /*
00023  * Copyright (c) 2007, 2010, Oracle and/or its affiliates. All rights reserved.
00024  * Use is subject to license terms.
00025  *
00026  * Copyright (c) 2011, 2014, Intel Corporation.
00027  *
00028  * Copyright 2015 Cray Inc, all rights reserved.
00029  * Author: Ben Evans.
00030  *
00031  * We assume all nodes are either little-endian or big-endian, and we
00032  * always send messages in the sender's native format.  The receiver
00033  * detects the message format by checking the 'magic' field of the message
00034  * (see lustre_msg_swabbed() below).
00035  *
00036  * Each wire type has corresponding 'lustre_swab_xxxtypexxx()' routines
00037  * are implemented in ptlrpc/lustre_swab.c.  These 'swabbers' convert the
00038  * type from "other" endian, in-place in the message buffer.
00039  *
00040  * A swabber takes a single pointer argument.  The caller must already have
00041  * verified that the length of the message buffer >= sizeof (type).
00042  *
00043  * For variable length types, a second 'lustre_swab_v_xxxtypexxx()' routine
00044  * may be defined that swabs just the variable part, after the caller has
00045  * verified that the message buffer is large enough.
00046  */
00047
